Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Forced Cooling of Semi-Permanent Molds for Fine Grain Steel Castings
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will demonstrate the feasibility of creating fine grain ultra-high strength steel (UHSS) castings using a novel semi-permanent active forced cooling mold casting manufacturing process. With the demand for low-cost high performance cast components for light-weighting applications for the defense, off-highway, automotive and construction industries, new manufacturing methods are needed for the production of steel and cast iron components. This innovation will utilize active cooling methods, effectively arresting the grain growth of the casting within the mold, and resulting in greatly improved mechanical properties, process yield and productivity. Compared to traditional sand casting, this process is predicted to reduce manufacturing cost per casting by up to 40%, and to increase productivity (casting throughput) by up to 150%. This disruptive technology targets the steel and other ferrous metal casting industry, which domestically accounts for over 10 million tons of steel castings annually, with revenues reaching $20 billion. This industry is highly fragmented, with frequent consolidation of smaller players. The proposed technology will be implemented at the foundry level, providing significant improvement in casting quality, operational efficiency, and overall casting yield.

The intellectual merit of this project includes the development of a semi-permanent mold casting system with active cooling, the determination of the effects of the active cooling on the performance of the produced castings, and a techno-economic study of the innovation in use at the foundry level to determine to costs/benefits of implementation at scale. The innovation of this technology lies in the application of active cooling to the casting within the mold, and in the semi-permanent mold construction. The main objective of this Phase I is to develop a proof-of-concept casting apparatus and to produce a series of steel plates with varying forced cooling rates from which to determine the effect of cooling rate in the mold on grain size, elongation, strength of the casting and soundness of the casting. It is anticipated that this manufacturing process will produce aerospace grade properties at cast iron manufacturing cost. Completion of this Phase I will enable scale up of the casting process to complex parts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Detroit Materials, Inc. (DM) is an advanced materials firm focused on the development and commercialization of nanostructured ultrahigh performance lightweight castings for chassis and drive-train applications in defense, off-highway, and transportation industries. Our portfolio of patented high-strength low-alloy structural steels (HSLA) exhibit an excellent combination of strength, toughness, hardness, and elongation only otherwise available in exotic high-alloy steels. DM steel is the highest strength low-alloy castable steel available.

In July, 2016 Detroit Materials was awarded an NSF SBIR Phase I for the development and proof of concept of a semi-permanent forced cooling mold system that would produce a fine grained ferrous casting. This technology would utilize in a novel fashion primary and secondary cooling of the cast alloy for the production of high tolerance net-shape castings, and would provide local control and direction of the cooling rate of the molten and semi-molten material. This would allow for the engineering of the grain size of the cast component while increasing the casting quality, reducing residual stresses and defects, while removing sand from the casting process, which would lower the cost and environmental impact of the casting process.

After completion of Phase I, Detroit Materials has developed a novel method to cast ferrous materials which produces a finely grained casting with an accelerated cooling rate compared to sand casting, dramatically improving the throughput of the casting process while completely eliminating environmentally hazardous emissions and waste. The results of this Phase I provide a compelling technical and business case that casting ferrous material (cast iron and steel) into a hard mold with forced cooling can provide improved mechanical properties, reduced material processing for final product, and dramatically reduce foundry capital and operating expenses while reducing foundry footprint.

Key accomplishments

•            Design and construction of semi-permanent mold featuring forced cooling able to produce ferrous castings

•            Casting demonstration of the forced cooled mold system with comparison to sand cast samples

•            Solidification simulation of the forced cooled mold casting process based on data accumulated during the casting demonstrations

•            A technoeconomic study to predict the production costs, throughput, and overall business case for this new casting technology

Detroit Materials is now working with Linamar, an automotive Tier 1, to further develop this technology for applications in the automotive, sporting goods, and heavy truck markets. The proof of concept provides the pathway towards the elimination of over 99% of the emissions associated with the conventional sand casting process which reduces costs, reduces foundry footprint, and can improve foundry working conditions. Further, the ability to strictly control the solidification of ferrous castings to dictate the grain size opens the door to a wide area of research concerning the effect on mechanical properties of cast components, as well as parts with anisotropic or inhomogeneous material properties.
